name: NPR
text:
The Secret Service says it's expanding a security perimeter around the White House â€” even as D.C.'s mayor calls on Trump to "withdraw all extraordinary federal law enforcement and military presence from our city."
https://t.co/IxdpBMXsXp

name: NPR
text:
In Bangladesh, there are no unemployment benefits, so textile factories workers â€” who survive paycheck-to-paycheck â€” were left without support when they closed due to coronavirus.

"I'll die of hunger before I die of this virus," one worker said. https://t.co/qiB5n0Wv5G

name: NPR
text: A few tips to help reduce your risk of coronavirus exposure during protests. https://t.co/5vhuC0AHRc https://t.co/teRe5XUQoZ

name: NPR
text:
Last week, President Trump declared he is ending the U.S. relationship with the World Health Organization.

But with no guidance from the White House, and a "dignified silence" from Geneva, the details of what happens next are unclear. https://t.co/8vzlQjlkOC

name: NPR
text:
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, in a letter to President Trump: "The practice of officers operating with full anonymity undermines accountability, ignites government distrust and suspicion, and is counter to the principle of procedural justice and legitimacy."
https://t.co/jn8EvcmVhw

name: NPR
text:
Tear gas makes people cough droplets â€” a primary way the coronavirus spreads. Deploying it could:
  
â€¢ expose more people to the virus
â€¢ compromise the body's ability to fight off the infection
â€¢ cause mild infections to become more severe illnesses https://t.co/HWlFoJOtbx

name: NPR
text: The top prosecutor in Omaha, Neb., will request a grand jury to take a second look at the shooting of James Scurlock, a 22-year-old African American man who was killed by a white bar owner Saturday night amid protests against police violence. https://t.co/aogGvonzLx

name: NPR
text:
Just a few weeks into its summer season, the seafood industry has been shaken by its first major COVID-19 outbreak.

Nearly three-fourths of the 126 people aboard a massive vessel with a fish processing factory have tested positive.
https://t.co/zJY9Gh91sz

name: NPR
text:
Across the world, artists are creating anthems for this moment. 

From @NPRMusic, here are some of the songs that have been released in the past week answering the world's call for music that reflects this historic movement. https://t.co/DGZpujRTro

name: NPR
text:
In the South, the timing of new coronavirus cases appears linked to the reopening of restaurants, barbershops and gyms.

Figures tracked by NPR show the number of cases in North Carolina and South Carolina this week is up by roughly 60% from two weeks ago.
https://t.co/A1j9Xb9K89

name: NPR
text:
CEO Mark Zuckerberg told Facebook employees on Friday that the social network will review how it handles some of the most incendiary posts on its platform, including those by President Trump.
https://t.co/69TrC2IDZx

name: NPR
text:
A judge at the U.S. military court in GuantÃ¡namo Bay has ruled that a prisoner there may be entitled to a more lenient sentence if he was tortured in CIA custody.

The decision could potentially apply to several other prisoners there.
https://t.co/DBAZfL5mMl

name: NPR
text:
Billy Dume says the police violence that shaped the Black Lives Matter movement never touched him directly. 

Then came the police killing of George Floyd, followed by an incident last weekend in Dume's neighborhood. https://t.co/2cwFswFeyU

name: NPR
text:
East Los Angeles' Candelas Guitars has a history stretching back 73 years and across two countries â€” but the coronavirus hit the business hard.

As they're trying to find new ways to make money, they know the revenue they're losing will never be recovered. https://t.co/VVEaZplP1r

name: NPR
text: "Mad Men" and "Handmaid's Tale" actress Elisabeth Moss joins @Bullseye to talk about her fascination with playing women accused of losing their minds -- as in her new movie, "Shirley" -- and her early role acting opposite Hulk Hogan. https://t.co/MnXWPYkMY9

name: NPR
text:
A 75-year-old Buffalo man was shoved by police at a protest Thursday night, and fell, hitting his head. He reportedly has a concussion and lacerations, but is expected to recover. 

Two officers have been suspended without pay. @WBFO https://t.co/Bsh2bnnMH4

name: NPR
text:
Aiden: "So Dad, why do you take me to protests so much?"

Albert: "I want you to see what it looks like when people come together."

Aiden: "What are your dreams for me?"

Albert: "My dream is for you to live out your dreams." https://t.co/N9vQUbezxw

name: NPR
text:
These five Tiny Desk songs feature calls to protest, cries for help, and messages of hope and rage. 

Watch the people who've helped to expose these societal woes to get a better understanding of where we were, where we are and where we could be. https://t.co/2xWAXBD3ma

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has ordered the Denver Police Department not to use chemical weapons or projectiles against peaceful protesters.

â€œThe Denver Police Department has failed in its duty to police its own." https://t.co/5W2SN1RlKz

name: NPR
text: Growing up, Orlando Watkins didn't get his mom's deep distrust of white people, he writes for @WBUR. Now raising two black sons of his own, he knows the fears she had for him. "I want you to see me. I want you to see my boys â€” to really see them. Can you?" https://t.co/o9EfIum5et

name: NPR
text: More than 75% of Chicagoâ€™s 93 district-run high schools have police stationed inside them. Local activists are looking to change that. (@WBEZ) https://t.co/KrqkenFDHM

name: NPR
text:
Music has power â€” especially in times of turmoil. 

On the newest episode of @AltLatino, we dig through the archives for musicians who demand social justice in song and action. https://t.co/IPCd8BhIco

name: NPR
text: When high schools shuttered across the country this spring, it deprived a lot of aspiring actors of their moments in the spotlight. @WCPN gave a few of them a chance to share their big musical numbers. https://t.co/Fmyn2tKU7q

name: NPR
text:
Brit Bennett never anticipated that when her newest book, "The Vanishing Half," came out it would be framed as "timely."

The story explores a set of African American twins in the Jim Crow era as they navigate not only society but defining themselves. 
 https://t.co/tQJRaEKWJ5

name: NPR
text:

name: NPR
text:
It's difficult to assess how protests will influence COVID-19 infections, modelers say.

But a key ingredient for transmission is present at many rallies: close contact.
